input:
Dortmund 3 - 2 Schalke

14:26 Caption: Schalke are showing great team chemistry. They are passing the ball around seamlessly.

15:45 Caption: A pass from Sead Kolasinac (Schalke) is intercepted by Roman Burki and the move breaks down.
15:58 Event: Foul by Schalke

16:45 Event: Ball out of play
17:00 Event: Throw-in by Schalke
17:52 Caption: Dortmund exchange some short passes over a small area and control the game. Now they make a mistake and lose the ball and the whole situation changes completely.

19:21 Event: Clearance by Dortmund
20:26 Event: Ball out of play
20:28 Caption: Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang (Dortmund) attempts to find one of his teammates, but puts far too much on the pass and the chance is gone. The ball is off of the pitch and it's a goal kick for Schalke.

22:06 Event: Clearance by Dortmund
22:19 Event: Ball out of play
22:46 Event: Clearance by Schalke

26:53 Event: Indirect free-kick by Dortmund

27:05 Event: Ball out of play

It's hard to say whether the keeper would have stopped it. Corner kick. Dortmund will have an opportunity.
27:35 Event: Corner by Dortmund
27:46 Caption: The resulting corner, taken by Henrikh Mkhitaryan (Dortmund), comes to nothing.
27:47 Event: Foul by Dortmund

30:45 Event: Kick-off by Schalke
31:19 Event: Ball out of play

31:31 Event: Throw-in by Schalke
32:05 Event: Shots on target by Schalke
32:06 Event: Goal by Schalke

33:07 Caption: Leroy Sane (Schalke) slides a pass forward, but one of the defenders cuts it out.
33:12 Event: Kick-off by Dortmund
34:37 Caption: Dortmund keep possession of the ball by producing short passes and one-two passes from player to player.
34:38 Event: Shots off target by Dortmund
34:39 Event: Ball out of play
34:44 Caption: What an opportunity! Ilkay Gundogan (Dortmund) picked the ball up and fired a projectile of a shot from long range which threatened the goalkeeper. The shot went painfully close to the right post!
35:16 Event: Clearance by Schalke
35:23 Event: Ball out of play
35:35 Event: Throw-in by Dortmund

36:10 Caption: Ilkay Gundogan (Dortmund) attempts to find one of his teammates with a ball from a free kick outside the box. The goalkeeper climbs high above all the players in the box to intercept the cross and snuff out the opportunity. The referee and his assistant both point at the corner flag. Dortmund will have an opportunity to threaten the opposition's goal.
36:22 Event: Direct free-kick by Dortmund
36:25 Event: Ball out of play

37:44 Event: Indirect free-kick by Dortmund

46:12 Caption: There will be nothing more to see in the first half. The whistle blowing of Felix Brych has ended it.
46:59 Caption: The players of both teams deserve praise from their managers and supporters for their performance on the pitch. If they continue playing this attractive football, the fans will surely be satisfied. The hosts dominated much of the first period. The home team are playing possession football, while the away team look to find a weakness in the opposition's defence mainly with their rapid counter-attacks.

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
The Signal Iduna Park was the venue for an electrifying Bundesliga encounter between Borussia Dortmund and Schalke 04. An intense rivalry matched by an equally intense match saw Dortmund narrowly edge past Schalke with a thrilling 3-2 victory.

The game got underway with Schalke kicking off. Within mere seconds, Schalke committed the first foul, setting the tone for a fiercely contested match. Dortmund promptly took an indirect free-kick, hinting at their tactical strategy to capitalise on set pieces. Not long after, Schalke's aggressive approach led to another foul, and once again, Dortmund took the set piece. These initial moments signaled Dortmund's intent to dominate, with Schalke struggling to find rhythm.

The frenetic pace continued with several instances of the ball going out of play, leading to frequent throw-ins and corner kicks. By the 10th minute, Ilkay Gundogan showcased his precision by picking out Matthias Ginter with a sublime lofted pass. This was an early indicator of Dortmund’s strategy to utilise their midfield's passing prowess.

Schalke’s Dennis Aogo tried to match Dortmund's creativity with his crossfield pass which ended in a lost possession. Dortmund maintained pressure with multiple throw-ins and corner kicks. Nonetheless, Schalke showed glimpses of their potential as they coordinated passes seamlessly around the 14th-minute mark.

The first real scare for Dortmund came in the 19th minute when a cross from Dennis Aogo found Leroy Sane, whose shot went narrowly wide of the left post. Both sides were exchanging possession and launching attacks, each testing the other's defensive solidity. By the 22nd minute, clearances, throw-ins, and indirect free-kicks occurred in rapid succession, but it was clear that Dortmund were gaining the upper hand in terms of possession and chances.

As the game neared the half-hour mark, Dortmund’s persistent efforts paid off. In the 30th minute, Matthias Ginter delivered a perfect cross into the box which Shinji Kagawa finished with a well-placed header, giving Dortmund a 1-0 lead.

The jubilation for Dortmund was short-lived. Schalke responded almost immediately, levelling the score in the 32nd minute. Leroy Sane’s assist allowed Klaas-Jan Huntelaar to finish close-range, making it 1-1. Schalke exhibited remarkable resilience, emphasizing the unpredictability of this classic fixture.

Despite the equaliser, Dortmund remained undeterred. They dictated play with their superior passing and pressing. Gundogan came close with a long-range effort that narrowly missed the right post in the 35th minute. They continued probing Schalke's defense, earning multiple free-kicks and corners.

Dortmund’s efforts to reclaim their lead bore fruit before halftime. In the 42nd minute, Henrikh Mkhitaryan's corner was met by Matthias Ginter, who headed the ball into the centre of the goal. Schalke’s goalkeeper had no response as Dortmund went into the break leading 2-1.

The first half ended with flurry of more throw-ins and stoppages, as both sides showcased intense competition and tactical awareness. Both teams displayed attractive football, epitomising the essence of the "Revierderby."

The second half began with Dortmund kicking off and immediately seizing the upper hand. The half opened with a yellow card for Schalke’s Junior Caicara following a blatant foul and immediately presented Dortmund with a promising free-kick. Gundogan sent a close effort just wide of the post, indicative of Dortmund's unrelenting pressure.

In the midst of Schalke’s attempts to regain composure, Dortmund extended their lead in the 2nd minute of the second half. Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang latched onto a visionary pass from Gonzalo Castro, displaying his characteristic composure to bury the ball into the bottom right corner, elevating Dortmund to a 3-1 lead.

Schalke found themselves grappling with Dortmund's control over the game, further complicated by a yellow card for Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang in the 3rd minute of the half. Despite the challenge, Schalke rallied. Ralf Fahrmann, Schalke’s goalkeeper, made a critical save from Ilkay Gundogan's strike, catching the shot aimed towards the left post.

Inserting fresh legs into the game, Schalke substituted Max Meyer with Maxim Choupo-Moting around the 10th minute of the half. This strategic change aimed to reinvigorate their attacking efforts. However, Dortmund continued to maintain possession, exchanging passes meticulously, making life difficult for the Schalke defence.

The game witnessed further action as Schalke’s Franco Di Santo received a yellow card in the 15th minute for a harsh tackle. This illustrated Schalke's struggle to keep up with Dortmund's attacking dynamics. Amidst the intense midfield battles and tactical fouls, both sides created chances but lacked the finishing touch.

Around the 26th minute, Dortmund were awarded a throw-in following Matthias Ginter's long ball, which was comfortably gathered by Ralf Fahrmann. Schalke’s attempt to play from the back saw them concede possession frequently, and Dortmund capitalised on these errors with threatening counter-attacks.

Despite Dortmund’s dominance, Schalke revealed their resilience once more. In a bolt from the blue, Klaas-Jan Huntelaar, capitalising on a precise pass, lifted the ball over Roman Burki from inside the box, scoring Schalke's second goal and bringing the score to 3-2 in the 25th minute of the second half. This goal reminded everyone why football is a game of unpredictability.

The match resumed with Dortmund attempting to sustain their slim lead, executing tactical fouls to quell Schalke's momentum. Substitutions became a key aspect as both teams sought to introduce fresh energy. Schalke's Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg replaced the injured Sead Kolasinac, while Dortmund substituted an attacking Aubameyang with a more conservative Adrian Ramos as the clock ticked.

As the game approached its closing stages, the tension was palpable. Schalke applied intense pressure, pushing for an equaliser. Romano Burki denied a brilliant late effort from Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg, highlighting the heightened defensive efforts from Dortmund to preserve their lead. The match's pace amplified with every passing minute, marked by short passes, strategic throw-ins, and decisive defensive clearances from both sides.

In a final tactical switch, Gonzalo Castro was replaced by Sven Bender around the 41st minute, indicative of Dortmund’s attempt to solidify their midfield and see out the game. Schalke persevered, sending long balls and crosses into Dortmund's penalty area, but to no avail. The game concluded amidst aggressive pressing, tactical fouls, and crucial saves.

As the final whistle blew, Dortmund emerged victorious in what was a thoroughly gripping encounter. Their strategy of controlling possession with short passes and exploiting set pieces paid dividends. Schalke, despite their rapid counter-attacks and moments of brilliance, fell short. The match highlighted the resilience and tactical depth of both teams, providing fans with an exhilarating display of football.

The final scoreline of 3-2 reflected Dortmund's superior game management and clinical finishing, amidst a backdrop of fierce rivalry and competitive spirit. This encounter will be remembered for its thrilling goals, tactical battles, and the relentless intensity that epitomizes the Borussia Dortmund-Schalke 04 rivalry.
